reviewText:
I have been seeing a lot of negative reviews that have little to do with the actual game, and I am fairly certain just from a glance that the ones that are giving these reviews are probably not from the targeted audience demographic and seem a bit unfair in my opinion. That being what it is I felt that writing a review of this game from the perspective of someone who is a fan of the genre was necessary.

First and foremost I can't get over how lovely the art is. Sprites, backgrounds, and CG's are all beautiful! It is very obvious that a lot of love and attention to detail was put into the visuals of this game, and the style is something new and refreshing. Also, the music is suprisingly great as well. The writing was really solid. The dialogue is believable. Characters have defined personalities and the plot is pretty interesting (I have seen the supernatural theme come up in a lot of otome games but the story has it's own world and lore makes it just a notch above other games with a similar theme) and the writing was pretty sound grammatically too and was void of any glaring typos. If a game of this genre has all of these things it is already superior to 90% of the games that are out there.

I have seen some complaints from other reviewers with the way the game is being distributed with the prologue and sneak peek of each route being free, and each full route being availible for individual sale as they are released. I for one don't mind this. I feel that each route is long enough that the price per route is fair, and if it allows me to play each route sooner since I don't have to wait for the whole game to be completed then I don't really see what the big deal is. If every route is just as long as Shou's route, there will be hours of play time for each character route, with multiple endings for each one.

To be honest I am pretty hyped up to play the routes as they become availible. I think this is shaping up to be a really great game!

********Okay so this is a long review just entirely my opinion. Basically, I rate this game like 9.5/10 definitely give it a try with what's given to you for free and see if it's your thing!************


Okay so the artwork, the story, the music (holy ♥♥♥♥ the music though...) and the personalities are all so wonderfully done in this game.

Tbh the artstyle threw me off at first because it was so different from what I'm used to seeing (really anime stuff, you know what I'm talking about) but it is so beautiful, the artwork. It's so well done and the background images look like they took /forever/ to create--it's all beautiful. The facial expressions and subtle differences from when they are blushing and aren't--it's amazing.

The music is probably my favorite thing about the game, though. It fits really nicely and it's just calming to listen to. I could just let it play for hours and never get bored of it. It fits the mood, whatever that may be, and really let's you get a little more immersed in the world.

The story!--it's really interesting! Now I definitely see a few things that they did wrong (completely in my OWN OPINION) but for the most part, the story is nice and original. There were some clichés in the story but nothing is forced and for the most part, it's nicely paced.

All the characters have their own personalities!!! (This one is just amazing) So like even the MC like...ACTUALLY has a personality for once. I CANNOT tell you how many god damn times that I've played a visual novel and then I had to stop because the MC is just so stupid. Honestly, the generic, pushover, girly girl type can only go so far and I am SO glad that they decided against making the MC like that. You can change her name to whatever you'd like and she is--mostly--calm and collected...also she's a nerd who loves anime and that in itself is great.

Overall, this game is really well done. When I'm writing this, there is only 2 routes out (Shou and Tatsuya's) and I've played through Shou's completely, and Tatsuya's halfway. But even so, I can tell that it's only going to get better from here. Please support this company and this game. I can't wait for the other routes to come out (though it may be quite a while before they do) because you can tell that these people actually care about their product.

Also Tatusya is and will be forever my favorite. He's such a dork omg I love him so much ;u;

So far I've played both Shou and Tatsuya's routes (but not shou's epilogue) for this game. Overall I'd give the game a 6/10 with Shou's route being better put together than Tatsuya's, imo.
----------------------------------

First off though I'd like to make a note about the marketing for this game. The game is stated as f2p with paid dlc. The free part is really just the prologue and the first chapters for each guy. The dlc is what you need to pay for to get the complete routes for each character. Now, this is really common in mobile dating sims/visual novels, where the aim seems to be to get the user to spend as much money as possible by splitting up the game into sections and then locking them behind price tags. At the same time this allows the game to have some content playable and ready, while working on additional content to be released later. And that's fine for mobile because you usually go in knowing that and it's a well-used strategy. But I don't think steam was the best place to launch this game with that type of business model (it's also not very common on here, hence all the angry/shocked reviewers of this game. I honestly think it would have been better to wait until all of the routes were finished and then release the game on steam with the entire price tag. It's what visual novel romance games that launched on mobile are starting to do: consolidating all the routes under one price tag and porting to steam. But it seems like the devs wanted to get the game out as soon as possible so they went this way, launching each route as it's ready and releasing it as paid dlc. Mystic Destinies: Serendipity of Aeons is a beautifully compelling story about a young woman called Tsubasa whose life is suddenly turned upside down when her mother drops the big reveal. The world she has always known has been a lie and now she must face the truth.  Aided by some new wonderful supportive friends, Tsubasa begins her journey into the Unseen World, the magical realms where supernatural beings lie hidden from the human realm. MDSoA introduces a rather interesting moral dilemma; what does it mean to be human?

StarMaidenGames has done a fantastic job with this game. They have listened to feedback from fans and have implemented changes that have really made this game shine. While it’s not the traditional ‘anime’ art style that comes with many otome games, the artist should be congratulated highly for such a beautiful style that highlights and captures the story in amazing ways. The characters are very well rounded and complement each other wonderfully. Character stereotypes have been broken apart and it’s such a nice sight to see. The story is complex but well-structured; there are moments of confusion, which I believe is well intended because like Tsubasa, we are experiencing this world for the first time. While it does leave some rather big questions open, this is the first route of the game and I do expect that they will be addressed in future routes.

Playing Mystic Destinies: Serendipity of Aeons will give you warm fuzzy feelings but it will also make you feel some angst as not everything is sunshine and roses. So if you’re ready to embark on a beautiful journey of self-acceptance, love and magic then press that purchase button and play until you cry. <3

Even though I supported this game's fundraising and was bound to play the other routes, I decided to jump in early and actually purchase the first route to see what I'll be expecting. :D

(If the prologue was disappointing in any way, I still suggest you try Shou's route, at least while his route is still price-reduced! I can say that it takes at least a good 5 hours to run through his route and get one of the 3 endings.)

Writing: Watching anime on TatamiRoll? Instant 10/10!
On a serious note, the writing in Shou's route is one the best I've seen from this genre of gaming. (Well, with the competition being larger companies and translations, the bar doesn't seem that high, but the humor is pretty decent.) Some options play out differently from what they would seem like, so it's not always clear which option is the best/worst--- I think that's a good thing.

Characters: 8/10
Well, with only Shou out, it's kinda hard to judge. Personally I'm waiting on other routes, but from what I saw Show isn't half bad of a character, though his development seems slow at times (then condensed at other times). Still, he gets plenty of interaction with the main character.
I'll also throw in the protagonist into this category. She seems somewhat relatable, but one thing I noticed is that
<spoiler alert?> she cries a ton, like...at least enough for me to feel dettached from her sometimes. <end spoiler alert?>
Still, this is being picky. The side characters, particularly the ones that don't have sprites, were probably the reason why I had to deduct some points here. I'm glad the father has a sprite, though.

Actual Plot: 8/10
I think the plot is unconventional in a way? The antagonist took me by surprise (I'm glad you gave the antagonist development though, even though it was treated like an afterthought in my opinion.)
For Shou, it was a straightfoward plot, and it kinda had a feel of many tropes that you've probably seen before in dramas and anime. I didn't notice huge changes in text from the choices made...perhaps the result of a very minor problem changes, but for the most part the plot is intact.

The foreshadowing and some elements of the plot were clear enough to predict, which does subtract from this rating, but just a little. Regardless, the writing does compensate for this greatly. I wish there were more moments involving fluff/comedy (there's plenty of angst and tension in the mix, though!), but having 3 endings was a nice touch.


Art: 9.99/10 (realistically, 9/10)
Oh bless the art staff. This game had some real love put into it. reviewText:
There are certain things you have to go through when you're an indie dev. With web comics, making music on youtube, hosting a podcast, making indie games, any online careers that have popped up in this day and age you have to make a few choices related to how you make your money when you start, get an audience keep making money and also keep your audience so that you can still keep doing what you're doing...

This is an example of how not to treat your audience...

I downloaded Mystic Destinies: Serendipity of Aeons for the sake of research (I'm a writer myself and I've been dabbling with visual novel creating softwares because one of my original works may end up working better in that format than in a novel or webcomic format.). Most of my Steam friends and all of my friends IRL will tell you i'm determined to be a web comic artist who doesn't rely on ads on their site in order to make money (because i hate those ads myself). I consider myself a very honest writer. I want to be funded completely by my audience if i can, if i absolutely must do sponsorships i'll only get sponsors that I have experience with or get sponsors related to products and services i have used and approved of, so on and so fourth. In this day and age, if you wanna go indie you need to be upfront and honest with your audience unless you want to end up like the shameful Digital Homicide (using an indie example) or perhaps worse: be accused of being your field's EA equivalent!

So seeing that this game was free to play and i wanted to study how some of my favorite visual novels worked, i downloaded this game under the impression i was getting a whole game... I did not. I got a prolouge and 1 chapter for free with 11 OTHER CHAPTERS behind a paywall...

Now putting some content behind a paywall i can understand... DLC, extra routes that may not appeal to everyone, sountracks, art collections, pre-order bonuses and other stuff like that which may not appeal to everyone i can understand charging for... But if you're gonna put 11 CHAPTERS OF YOUR VISUAL NOVEL BEHIND A PAY WALL, then why not just charge for the game outright?

Speaking for myself in particular my webcomic is still in the process. The story is worked on in a unique way where things are subject to change so no storyboarding gets done until things are final. I have an editor to keep me in line so i don't do anything stupid, but who also makes sure i get stuff done. Currently my web comics have no budget in particular and i do all of the art, 90% of the writing and a good chunk of any research i need for it myself. I don't have a site because I know full well I don't have much material to display currently, and if you have no finished product, you shouldn't post at all... That only makes sense!

That's my main complaint about this game...

They paraded it like a free to play game that you could download and enjoy in it's entirety but once you finish chapter one you realize Oh... Only the first chapter was free. Now they expect me to pay..." For that
